text: [Music]
hello this is chef john from
foodwishes.com
with
italian sausage chili
that's right after tasting this you
won't be asking where's the beef you'll
be asking hey why were we using beef for
chili it's so much better like this and
if you're watching this in real time and
you're planning food for your super bowl
party what better choice than a super
bowl of food and that's exactly what
this is and here's one of the big
reasons italian sausage so i'm going to
use two kinds i got some hot italian and
i got some sweet italian and step one
here we're going to want to remove the
casing which is very simple just take
the tip of a knife and slice down
lengthwise and you'll be able to peel
that casing right off and after i do
that i like to break it up a little bit
so i did three spicy and three mild that
was about two and a half pounds of
sausage total and then once that's
prepped we can head over to the stove to
start browning this so i'm gonna place a
pot over medium-high heat with a little
bit of olive oil in there and to that
i'm gonna add one diced onion
and then we'll go ahead and dump in our
recently skinned and crumbled sausage
along with a spoon of salt and like i
said we're going to go ahead and brown
this but as it comes up to temperature i
want you to take some kind of wooden
spoon or spatula and break this up as
much as you can the smaller the pieces
the better and because we started in a
cold pot with all those onions this
meat's going to start cooking very
slowly so it's very easy to crumble at
this point if you let those chunks of
meat cook and then you try to break them
up it doesn't work as well so really get
in there and break it up as much as you
can
until it resembles something that looks
like this
at this point you probably will notice a
good amount of liquid at the bottom
that's perfectly fine and do not drain
it if you have a chili recipe that calls
for draining the meat after you brown it
go ahead and cross that part out don't
drain your meat and i will explain why
on the blog instead we're just going to
keep cooking this and most of that
excess liquid is going to evaporate out
and or caramelize onto the meat itself
so that's all we're going to do we're
just going to continue to keep cooking
until that meat is browned and most of
the liquid has evaporated which for me
was right about here at that point we
are ready for our top secret spice blend
which includes chili powder paprika
chipotle chili powder
some cumin
some freshly ground black pepper and a
little bit of dry oregano and we'll go
ahead and stir that in and you know this
trick we like to saute our spices if we
can in fat before we add the wet
ingredients in fact there's an old
culinary school saying that i just made
up that goes before you get the wet be
sure to fry the dry and i know
technically we're not frying the spices
but saute didn't rhyme but anyway dump
in those spices and cook that stirring
for about two minutes
and then and only then will we introduce
the wet stuff which includes some water
and some crushed tomato and you'll
notice i'm not using a ton of tomato i
hate when chilies are actually tomato
sauces in fact i don't even think real
chili has tomato in it but i'll have to
check with my friends from texas on that
one oh they'll know and then i want you
to bring this up to a simmer and then
adjust your heat to maintain a nice slow
steady simmer should look something like
that
and all we're going to do is simmer that
for about 45 minutes or until that
sausage meat is tender and by the way
like any stew soup or chili you can
always add a little water as you go if
it looks like it's getting too thick or
dry so it's just something to keep an
eye on and then one other thing we want
to do is make sure we skim any fat that
floats to the top off with a ladle which
by the way i will do most of off camera
since seven seconds of watching
someone's skin fat is plenty but anyway
let it simmer for 45 minutes stirring
occasionally skimming the fats and after
45 minutes it's time to test so this was
me 45 minutes later checking and as i
suspected after 45 minutes that sausage
meat was tender and at that point we're
ready to add our beans and because we're
doing an italian sausage chili we're
going to use an italian white bean
called the cannellini bean and not only
does this large white bean taste great
in this it looks great especially along
with the next ingredient which is diced
red and green bell pepper so we'll go
ahead and stir in the beans and the
peppers and i'm using sweet peppers you
can use spicy of course i can't believe
you even asked that and then we're going
to go ahead and simmer this for about 30
minutes but before we do i'm going to
add one more big splash of water and
depending how yours looks you may need a
little more water you may need a little
less you have to decide you are the
uncle billy of your italian sausage
chili so take control and you can see
right there that is the recommended
ideal viscosity and then like i said
bring this back to a simmer and let it
simmer for about 20-30 minutes and at
that point you should be ready to eat
and you'll know for sure because you're
gonna taste it for final seasoning you
might need some salt it's gonna depend
on how salty the sausage meat was to
start with and by the way if you're
wondering why i didn't put any garlic in
here it's because there was already a
ton in the sausage so that saved me a
step and once we decide it's exactly how
we want we're going to go ahead and grab
a ladle
and you can see right there how i like
mine
not too thick not too thin just right
and then we go ahead and ladle that up
into some hot bowls
and i don't know why i use that bowl i
hate that bowl but anyway we're gonna
ladle that up i'm gonna go ahead and
garnish with some sour cream some diced
avocado a little bit of minced red onion
and then last but not least and i hope
you're sitting down instead of cilantro
i'm gonna do some basil all right since
we used italian sausage and cannellini
beans i thought i would continue the
theme with a little bit of basil
chiffonade and that was one beautiful
looking and tasting bowl of chili and as
i dig in here what i'm really struck
with is that this does taste pretty much
exactly like a classic american chili
con carne and yet that pork sausage is a
little bit richer than the beef and also
you get that little bit of subtle herb
and spice from the sausage like the
garlic and the fennel and the pepper etc
so just really a beautiful variation on
your traditional chili and of course as
you'll notice here i like to serve mine
with polenta chips yup that's stone
ground corn fried into a chip really
good with this but don't worry if you
can't find polenta chips just use
tortilla chips they're remarkably
similar but anyway all in all just a
great bowl of chili and like i said at
the beginning this would be perfect the
next time you're entertaining at a party
super bowl or otherwise so i really do
hope you give this a try head over to
foodwishes.com for all the ingredient
amounts and more info as usual and as
always enjoy
[Music]
